message_1: A sample of radioactive material has an initial mass of 500 grams and a half-life of 10 days. How much of the material remains after 20 days?
message_2:
To find out how much of the radioactive material remains after 20 days, we can use the formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 500 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 20 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 500 * (1/2)^(20 / 10)
Final mass = 500 * (1/2)^2
Final mass = 500 * (1/4)
Final mass = 125 grams

So, after 20 days, 125 grams of the radioactive material remains.
